comments.commentBody: Hmm, what were you looking at? Apparently there was a little glitch in the reporting system.
its like the least evil of the two wins

Why not start investigating and harassing all Catholic New Yorkers of Italian ancestry looking for mob connections? Last I heard the mob is still in business in New York.

Terrorizing an entire community and creating an atmosphere of distrust, resentment and fear by any government and any police force should not be allowed to happen in this country, a country which is home to many diverse populations and religions. We have become a country of scared people willing to do anything to "defend" ourselves, internationally and domestically. At the end of this road we will find ourselves not only less safe, but citizens of a country which lost its soul along the way.

When the Dancing with the Stars roster was announced, I was so hoping to find Newt Gingrich among those appearing this year, but of course, that was premature, as he is still dancing to his own drummer in the Fifteen Minutes of Fame Republican National Talent Show.  Following in the great tradition of Tom DeLay, perhaps next year DWTS can also nab Donald Trump, Rick Perry, Michele Bachmann, Herman Cain and Ron Paul.  By then, Newt will be once again ready to dance, and they can sign him, too.  I imagine Jon Hunstman and Tim Pawlenty will have enough dignity to decline an invitation from DWTS, but then what do I know?  No one, but no one could have predicted this primary season, who knows how this cast of characters will chose to cash in in 2013.

Forty percent were Democrats or Independents?  Clearly, they found Santorum unacceptable.  Bet there were a lot of people who believe that individuals and not churches or employers should make the decisions about contraceptives turned out.  Particularly after they got the Santorum robo-calls.
I think I mean graves!
Good-bye and good riddance to Mr. Gridlock.  Politics is polarized enough without his re-emergence.
I was thinking about voting for Gary Johnson.  I wish he was talked about more.

I'm also a Roemer donor and sometime supporter. I don't really understand the anger I hear behind your words, but I have not research Roemer's past in-depth. I disagree with him pretty intensely on a lot of issues, but I agree with him strongly enough about money in politics that I will support him as far as he can go. Or, at least far enough for him to be heard on the national stage.
As for his compromising his values, I'm not sure AE or the Reform Party will cause that. AE does not directly finance candidates, they are just promising to get whomever wins their primary onto the ballot in every state (if I understand correctly). But regardless, I'm not so sure Roemer can win much at all if he doesn't get some additional money from somewhere. It's a little chicken-and-egg: you can't clean up Washington if you can't afford the price at the door. So I'm not too worked up about that -- Roemer strikes me as pretty sincere on the campaign-finance-reform front.
But the larger issue is that America needs a strong, viable third party (and maybe more!). The two-party system is too polarized and seems to filter out a lot of good ideas. To create a third party, I think we need a multi-election initiative with a lot of money, unfortunately.

To send back to Washington, as our new president, an ousted Washington career politician...is insane. It could never happen.

Santorum and Gingrich may have swayed some Tea Party people and evangelical Christians to their side, but the majority of Americans would reject them in a match against President Obama.

Ron Paul may be controversial...yet he is unashamedly honest, calling Santorum a "fake." One politician to another. It is safe to say, that 90% of Congress may fall in that bunch.

You should think longer term. If we had had a third party for the past hundred years, then what? That's what we're talking about. Of course if you look at just one election you will see one candidate playing 'spoiler' to another.
Also, I'm not sure the kind of specific results you mention above (Iraq, Alito, etc.) should be our measure of the success of our political process. A more transparent, responsive, and representative democracy is in and of itself of huge value, from my point of view. And the two parties do tremendous damage to all three of those characteristics, IMHO.

If we want a third party candidate to get far, it will take a real third party.  This will take a long time to build, but I don't see why it's impossible.  It's certainly desirable to have other points of view and other voices to hold those in power to account.  Something like Americans Elect is at least struggling against what seem to be unfair barriers to entry for new political parties.

I agree that there definitely seem to be more Republican-supporters on AE than Democrats.  I think that's because Democrats are all sitting tight, ready to rally around Obama, so they aren't looking for new ideas or possibilities.  Also, Americans Elect is mostly online (so far as I know), so of course young digital types are the majority on there, and they tend to skew towards libertarian views (not that this is a good or intelligent stance, IMHO).  I think *that* is the main problem with AE, so far -- their constituency seems extremely different from the vast majority of Americans.  But it's better than nothing, that's for sure!  Hopefully it's a start.

AAC: You are seriously flaunting Romney's honesty? When he changes his convictions whenever it suits him? Obama has already started to lead us out of a GOP administration-induced recession but what has been destroyed over a period of 8 years just can't be fully fixed in 3 or 4 years. A few sticks of dynamite can topple a huge bridge or edifice in seconds. Rebuilding these would take a bit longer, wouldn't you think?

And just when the Obama's strategy is starting to work, you want to go back to the GOP who are the cause of our financial and economic problems today?

How hare-brained is that?

The only people obsessed with his wealth are his critics. His supporters pretty much know who he is and respect him for it. "Tin ear" and "gaffe-prone" are minor compared to his being intelligent, hard working, honest, etc.

Voters interested in honestly assessing Romney versus Obama are not likely to consider Romney's bank account or the number of cars he owns. They will be looking at which candidate will be better able to lead us out of this recession and get people back to work.

Although the media love them as a presumed voting block, that may be just another media bias that Christian evangelicals can be a predictive voting group.  It may just be that they are a great deal more discriminating than the media pretend.  Why else would they be "all over the place" in their voting this year?

"My name's PAVLOV, ring a bell?"
I spotted a glaring EROS @66A as HOWIE requires five (5) boxes in the grid! HEHE

HAVOC lovely evening
WHH

My God, even if Romney loses a bit in Michigan, it is obviously very tight victory. Santorum is irritating me. He is no man for any nomination.It is pitiful that Paul can't win, but it truly looks like he can't So, White House would be Romney's. I would nevertheless vote for Paul on Super Tuesday. At least later, when Romney would escalate
war, I wouldn't feel remorse and guilt. But Romney looks more and more like our new president.

“We need to have a candidate who can take President Obama on in this biggest issue of the day, of government control of our lives.”

And that's you, Mr. Santorum? You wouldn't even let me control my own body, or who I marry.
What do you expect from a state that essentially voted George W. Bush in for a second term?
Vote for this guy and your kids will come home from school armed with new knowledge of how the Earth and Universe are only 6000 years old!

To my fellow Ohio citizens,please nominate Ricky boy in the primary.He defines the clear lines between Republicans and Democrats.He does this so well,that I believe that if he is the Republican partys nominee for President,that he will alter the course of our country.He will change things in a POSITIVE direction!President Obama will defeat him in the general election,and he will stop the dangerous progression of like minded ,dangerous conservatives.He lays open the wounds that the T-party people have caused,and will likely damage the GOP ,in conjunction with Gov. K-sick,for the next generation or two,in the Great state of Ohio.The Reagan Democrats will become,just that! DEMOCRATS!

The first amendment applies to Congress, and by extension all other legislatures in the US. It specifically denies Congress the power to make laws either for or against the personal practice of religion.

The phrase "there shalt be a separation between thy church and thy state" does not appear in the Constitution. However, the First Amendment states, "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof..." meaning "there shalt be a separation between thy church and thy state."

Yet Santorum accuses “our culture, our education system’’ of falsely “teaching our children that separation of church and state” is mentioned in the Constitution.

Either Santorum doesn't understand the First Amendment or he doesn't understand that Amendments to the Constitution are part of the Constitution. He also doesn't seem to realize that some voters take the Constitution seriously - much more seriously, it appears, than Mr. Santorum. (Parenthetically, this may be why Mr. Santorum is opposed to higher education - educated people are capable of critical thinking.) Based on these observations Mr. Santorum is unqualified to be President.
Rick Santorum is an awful man (politically). That he gets so much support sickens me.
I wonder what to read into the low turnout mentioned here.

Finally some common sense in this comment stream.
But, familyisok - the point these commenters are making is that no matter how young women speak, those who want to delegitimatize their voices will always find a way to criticize it. Speak too high - shrill and childish. Speak too low - disrespectful and bossy.
Also, incidentally, I wonder if women use filler words because they've learned that a man will use any pause in their speech as an opportunity to interject with his own clearly-more-important thoughts.
